questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports episodes of palpitations and dizziness, particularly following physical activity such as playing tennis. She has experienced these symptoms multiple times over the last two years. ECG is taken and it is shown. Based on her presentation and the accompanying ECG findings, which of the following diagnoses is most likely? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epsilon waves on ECG are pathognomonic for ARVD, which typically presents in young people with exertional symptoms and can be a cause of sudden cardiac death, particularly common in Italy. The condition involves desmosomal mutations and progressive RV dysfunction.

questions.text: A scuba diver surfaces rapidly, soon experiencing joint pain, dizziness, and difficulty breathing indicating decompression sickness. Which of the following is not associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Haemodilution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decompression sickness leads to hemoconcentration (not haemodilution) and can present with joint pain ("the bends"), neurological symptoms, coagulopathy, and sensory organ dysfunction including vision and hearing loss.

questions.text: High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) is not caused by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

questions.text: Acute graft rejection in a kidney transplant patient is indicated by: (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Not associated with rise in Creatinine

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Any rise in creatinine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute graft rejection in kidney transplant patients typically presents with asymptomatic elevation in serum creatinine. Traditional symptoms like fever and graft tenderness are less common due to current immunosuppression protocols. Any rise in creatinine should prompt consideration of acute rejection.

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium and his BP was 220/110 mmHg. He also had one episode of vomiting and on examination has weakness in the left upper and lower limbs. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives

options.label: B
options.text: In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives

options.label: C
options.text: In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives

options.label: D
options.text: BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

questions.correct_answer: D. BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific blood pressure targets in acute stroke:
  • ➤ General recommendation in hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in 1st hour, then target around 160/100 mmHg within 2–6 hours Ischemic stroke with thrombolysis: <185/110 mmHg Ischemic stroke without thrombolysis: <220/120 mmHg Hemorrhagic Stroke: Controversial – SBP <140 mmHg (INTERACT2) vs. 140–180 mmHg (WHO 2021)
  • ➤ General recommendation in hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in 1st hour, then target around 160/100 mmHg within 2–6 hours
  • ➤ Ischemic stroke with thrombolysis: <185/110 mmHg
  • ➤ Ischemic stroke without thrombolysis: <220/120 mmHg
  • ➤ Hemorrhagic Stroke: Controversial – SBP <140 mmHg (INTERACT2) vs. 140–180 mmHg (WHO 2021)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation following CPR? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

options.label: C
options.text: Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG

options.label: D
options.text: Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: B. Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-resuscitation care after ROSC, targeted temperature management should be maintained between 33–36°C, with higher targets (36–37.5°C) for patients at risk of bleeding or coagulopathy. Temperature should never be targeted below 33°C due to increased complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

options.label: C
options.text: Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.correct_answer: B. Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic triad of APS-1:
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation) Hypoparathyroidism Addison's disease
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  • ➤ Hypoparathyroidism
  • ➤ Addison's disease

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic pentad of TTP consists of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and neurological involvement. Macrovascular thrombosis is not a defining feature of TTP, unlike in conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome, where both macro- and microvascular thrombosis can occur.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Behçet's disease? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria

options.label: B
options.text: Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

options.label: C
options.text: Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Behçet’s disease typically affects the scrotum, vulva, eyes, and oral mucosa. Ulcers on the dorsum of the penis are atypical, making option B the incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024) Brown urine Dysuria absent Crystals in urine Edema is rare
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A, B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating. Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine synthesis.

questions.text: Match the following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The distinct receptor mechanisms for different hormone classes:
  • ➤ Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated channels Insulin → Tyrosine kinase pathway Growth hormone → JAK-STAT pathway Thyroxine → Nuclear receptors
  • ➤ Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated channels
  • ➤ Insulin → Tyrosine kinase pathway
  • ➤ Growth hormone → JAK-STAT pathway
  • ➤ Thyroxine → Nuclear receptors

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

options.label: A
options.text: Making a fist with forearm exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible

options.label: C

options.text: Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection

questions.correct_answer: A. Making a fist with forearm exercise

Ans. A) Making a fist with forearm exercise

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the synthesis of TG and VLDL is increased from the liver. What is the cause of the same? (INICET NOV 2024)

Ans. A) Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HLA B27

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis , particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.
  • ➤ limited systemic sclerosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PNH is an acquired (not hereditary) stem cell disorder caused by somatic mutations in the PIG-A gene. Protein C deficiency, Factor V Leiden mutation, and Antithrombin III deficiency are hereditary causes of thrombophilia.
  • ➤ acquired
  • ➤ hereditary

questions.text: What is the most common cause of inherited Thrombophilia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.
  • ➤ Factor V Leiden mutation

questions.text: In haemolytic anaemia, which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024) Urobilinogen is high Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated Serum transaminases are increased Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4

  • ➤ Haemolytic anaemia is characterized by:
  • ➤ Increased urobilinogen in urine Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction Normal enterohepatic circulation
  • ➤ Increased urobilinogen in urine
  • ➤ Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin
  • ➤ Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction
  • ➤ Normal enterohepatic circulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.correct_answer: D. HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is genetically associated with HLA-DQ2 (95% of cases) and HLA-DQ8 , not HLA-DQ6 and HLA-DQ11.
  • ➤ HLA-DQ2
  • ➤ HLA-DQ8

questions.text: Which mutation is seen in sickle cell disease? (INICET NOV 2024)

Ans. A) Glu → Val (6)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val) .
  • ➤ glutamic acid (Glu)
  • ➤ valine (Val)

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic presented with fever, malaise, and cough. His chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Aspiration pneumonia – Upper segment of right lower lobe

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Interstitial infiltrates – Mycoplasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, along with fever, malaise, and cough, are characteristic of atypical pneumonia , particularly Mycoplasma pneumonia .
  • ➤ Bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates
  • ➤ atypical pneumonia
  • ➤ Mycoplasma pneumonia

questions.text: What is the normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2:3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The normal arteriovenous (AV) ratio at the optic disc is 2:3. This ratio represents the normal relationship between arteriole and venule caliber at the optic disc. The artery appears lighter in color and has a thicker wall, while the vein appears darker and has a thinner wall. This ratio is important in assessing various ocular conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2:5 : This is incorrect as it suggests arterioles are too narrow compared to venules. This ratio would indicate pathological narrowing of arterioles.
  • • Option A. 2:5
  • • Option C. 1:5 : This is incorrect and would represent a severely abnormal ratio suggesting significant arteriolar narrowing, which might be seen in advanced hypertensive retinopathy.
  • • Option C. 1:5
  • • Option D. 1:3 : While this ratio is seen in hypertensive retinopathy, it is not the normal AV ratio. In hypertensive retinopathy, there is narrowing of arterioles leading to a reduction in the AV ratio from 2:3 to 1:3.
  • • Option D. 1:3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc is 2:3, which serves as a baseline for evaluating vascular changes in various retinal conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.text: In the case of macular corneal opacity, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Both iris details and pupil margins are seen.

options.label: D
options.text: Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pupil margins are seen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In macular corneal opacity, the iris details are not visible through the opacity, but the pupil margin can be easily seen. This is a key distinguishing feature of macular opacity compared to other types of corneal opacities. Macular opacity involves significant stromal injury but affects less than half the depth of the stroma. The opacity is easily visible but allows some visualization of deeper structures like pupillary margins.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Iris details are seen : This is incorrect. In macular opacity, the texture and details of the iris are obscured by the opacity.
  • • Option A. Iris details are seen
  • • Option C. Both iris details and pupil margins are seen : This is incorrect and better describes nebular opacity, which is the mildest form where both iris details and pupil margins are visible.
  • • Option C. Both iris details and pupil margins are seen
  • • Option D. Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen : This is incorrect and describes leucomatous opacity, which is the densest form where neither iris details nor pupil margins are visible.
  • • Option D. Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Macular corneal opacity, pupil margins are visible while iris details cannot be seen - this is a key diagnostic feature that helps differentiate it from other types of corneal opacities.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child who was born premature at 34 weeks POG weighing 1400 gms presents with leukocoria. On CT, intraocular calcification is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • While the history of prematurity (34 weeks) and low birth weight (1400g) might suggest ROP, the presence of intraocular calcification on CT scan is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood, and it is the only condition among the given options that shows intraocular calcification. This calcification can be detected on CT scan, though CT is generally avoided due to radiation exposure risks. The preferred imaging modalities are ultrasound B-scan and contrast-enhanced MRI.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity): While the premature birth and low birth weight are risk factors for ROP, it does not present with intraocular calcification. ROP occurs in newborns <34 weeks or <2.0 kg birth weight and presents with abnormal vessel development.
  • • Option A. ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity):
  • • Option B. Congenital Cataract: This presents as leukocoria but does not show intraocular calcification. It is an opacity of the natural lens that is present at birth.
  • • Option B. Congenital Cataract:
  • • Option D. Coat's Disease: While this can present with leukocoria, it is characterized by retinal telangiectasia and exudation without calcification. It typically affects young males and is usually unilateral.
  • • Option D. Coat's Disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraocular calcification seen on imaging in a child with leukocoria is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma, regardless of other clinical factors like prematurity.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diabetic retinopathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss is most commonly associated with diabetic retinopathy , particularly in cases of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) leading to vitreous hemorrhage .
  • • painless
  • • diabetic retinopathy
  • • proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • • vitreous hemorrhage
  • • Diabetic retinopathy can cause vitreous hemorrhage , which results in sudden, painless vision loss. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is characterized by neovascularization, which can rupture and cause bilateral involvement due to systemic nature of diabetes. Unlike other causes of vision loss, diabetic retinopathy progresses asymptomatically until a significant event like hemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment occurs.
  • • Diabetic retinopathy can cause vitreous hemorrhage , which results in sudden, painless vision loss.
  • • Diabetic retinopathy
  • • vitreous hemorrhage
  • • painless
  • • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is characterized by neovascularization, which can rupture and cause bilateral involvement due to systemic nature of diabetes.
  • • bilateral involvement
  • • Unlike other causes of vision loss, diabetic retinopathy progresses asymptomatically until a significant event like hemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment occurs.
  • • diabetic retinopathy progresses asymptomatically
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Iridocyclitis: Incorrect. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) causes painful vision loss with redness, photophobia, and keratic precipitates , which are absent in this case.
  • • Option B. Iridocyclitis:
  • • painful
  • • redness, photophobia, and keratic precipitates
  • • Option C. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: Incorrect. This condition presents with sudden onset painful vision loss , red eye , halos around lights , and raised intraocular pressure . The presence of pain distinguishes it from diabetic retinopathy.
  • • Option C. Acute Congestive Glaucoma:
  • • sudden onset painful vision loss
  • • red eye
  • • halos around lights
  • • raised intraocular pressure
  • • pain
  • • Option D. Keratoconus: Incorrect. Keratoconus leads to progressive rather than sudden vision loss and is not typically bilateral at onset. It causes irregular astigmatism but does not cause complete vision loss suddenly.
  • • Option D. Keratoconus:
  • • progressive
  • • sudden

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral sudden painless vision loss is most commonly due to diabetic retinopathy , particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) with vitreous hemorrhage .
  • ➤ diabetic retinopathy
  • ➤ proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • ➤ vitreous hemorrhage
  • ➤ Diminished Vision Classification

questions.text: Arrange the following layers of the retina in the correct order from the outermost to the innermost layer. (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

options.label: B
options.text: 1 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 2 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 3 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 4 – Inner Plexiform Layer

options.label: C
options.text: 1 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 4 – Outer Nuclear Layer

options.label: D
options.text: 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost is RPE, outer nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, and ganglion cell layer. The RPE is the outermost layer of the retina, followed by the outer nuclear layer which contains photoreceptor cell bodies. The inner plexiform layer contains synapses between bipolar, amacrine, and ganglion cells, while the ganglion cell layer, containing ganglion cell bodies, is closest to the vitreous.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anatomical sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost:
  • ➤ Retinal Pigment Epithelium → Outer Nuclear Layer → Inner Plexiform Layer → Ganglion Cell Layer.

questions.text: Pterygium can lead to which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Astigmatism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pterygium can lead to astigmatism because the fibrous growth on the cornea tends to flatten the cornea in the horizontal meridian. This creates an irregular corneal surface, specifically causing with-the-rule astigmatism. The pterygium grows along the horizontal axis, making it flatter, which results in the vertical axis becoming comparatively steeper, leading to astigmatism. This condition may cause visual disturbance, especially if it grows across the pupil.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Eye Pain : This is incorrect. Pterygium is typically painless. Patients may experience foreign body sensation, but actual pain is not a characteristic feature.
  • • Option B. Eye Pain
  • • Option C. Macular edema : This is incorrect. Pterygium is a surface growth that affects the anterior segment of the eye and does not cause macular edema, which is a condition affecting the posterior segment.
  • • Option C. Macular edema
  • • Option D. Purulent Discharge : This is incorrect. Pterygium is a non-inflammatory condition and does not cause purulent discharge. While there might be mild irritation and tearing, purulent discharge is not associated with pterygium.
  • • Option D. Purulent Discharge

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterygium can cause with-the-rule astigmatism by flattening the cornea in the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice for Best disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electrooculogram (EOG)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease. EOG is the only condition where best disease has significant diagnostic value, and Best disease is the only condition where EOG is of primary diagnostic significance. In Best disease, the Arden ratio (peak to trough ratio) in EOG is abnormal (<1.5) while ERG remains normal in early stages. EOG measures the standing potential between the front and back of the eye and is particularly sensitive to RPE function, which is primarily affected in Best disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Electroretinogram (ERG) :This is incorrect because ERG is typically normal in Best disease, especially in early stages. ERG measures the electrical response of the retina to light stimulation and primarily tests photoreceptor function.
  • • Option B. Electroretinogram (ERG)
  • • Option C. Visual Evoked potential : This is incorrect because VEP tests the integrity of the entire visual pathway from retina to occipital cortex and is not specific for Best disease. It records the electrical activity in the visual cortex in response to visual stimuli.
  • • Option C. Visual Evoked potential
  • • Option D. Multifocal electro retinogram : This is incorrect because mfERG, while useful for evaluating macular function, is not the primary diagnostic test for Best disease. It provides topographic measurement of retinal electrophysiological activity in the central retina.
  • • Option D. Multifocal electro retinogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease, with an abnormal Arden ratio (<1.5) being diagnostic while ERG remains normal in early stages.

questions.text: In case of a chemical injury to the eye, what is the immediate first step in the management? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Copious irrigation with saline

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In chemical injury to the eye, copious irrigation with saline is the immediate first step in management. The primary goal is to remove the offending agent as quickly as possible to minimize tissue damage. Irrigation should be started immediately using whatever solution is available (saline, Ringer's lactate, balanced salt solution, or even plain water). It's crucial not to use neutralizing solutions (like acid for alkali or vice versa) as this can generate heat and cause additional damage.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Check visual acuity : This is incorrect as checking visual acuity would delay the urgent need to remove the causative chemical agent. Visual acuity can be checked after initial irrigation.
  • • Option A. Check visual acuity
  • • Option B. Take history : This is incorrect. While history is important, it should not delay immediate irrigation. Basic history (type of chemical) can be taken while performing irrigation.
  • • Option B. Take history
  • • Option C. Intraocular pressure measurement : This is incorrect. IOP measurement has no role in immediate management of chemical injury and could potentially cause more harm if done before thorough irrigation.
  • • Option C. Intraocular pressure measurement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate copious irrigation with saline or any available appropriate solution is the first step in managing chemical injury to the eye, taking precedence over all other examinations or investigations.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically seen in diabetic retinopathy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tractional retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tractional retinal detachment (TRD) is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). In PDR, new vessels proliferate and are accompanied by fibrous tissue formation. When this fibrous tissue contracts, it pulls on the retina, leading to tractional retinal detachment. This typically occurs as a late complication of PDR, following vitreous hemorrhage and fibrovascular proliferation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Myopic refractive error : This is incorrect. Myopic refractive error is not associated with diabetic retinopathy. It is a refractive condition where light focuses in front of the retina rather than on it.
  • • Option B. Myopic refractive error
  • • Option C. Posterior staphyloma : This is incorrect. Posterior staphyloma is typically associated with high myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It represents an outward bulging of the posterior pole of the eye.
  • • Option C. Posterior staphyloma
  • • Option D. Retinoschisis : This is incorrect. Retinoschisis, which is a splitting of the retinal layers, is not a characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. It is commonly seen in degenerative conditions and as a congenital condition.
  • • Option D. Retinoschisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tractional retinal detachment is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, caused by the contraction of fibrovascular tissue that develops with neovascularization.

questions.text: In fluorescein angiography, how do microaneurysms typically appear? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyperfluorescent dots

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In fluorescein angiography (FFA), microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots. Microaneurysms are focal saccular dilatations of capillary walls where pericytes are absent, typically located in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer. When fluorescein dye is injected, these microaneurysms fill with the dye and appear as bright, well-defined hyperfluorescent dots, particularly visible at the edge of areas of capillary non-perfusion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypofluorescent spots : This is incorrect. Hypofluorescent spots are typically seen in areas of blockage (like hemorrhages) or capillary dropout, not microaneurysms.
  • • Option A. Hypofluorescent spots
  • • Option C. Fluorescent leakage : This is incorrect. While microaneurysms may eventually leak, their characteristic initial appearance is as discrete hyperfluorescent dots, not diffuse leakage.
  • • Option C. Fluorescent leakage
  • • Option D. Dark shadows : This is incorrect. Dark shadows or blocking defects are typically seen with hemorrhages or pigmented lesions, not microaneurysms.
  • • Option D. Dark shadows

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots on fluorescein angiography, serving as an important diagnostic feature in conditions like diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery.

options.label: B
options.text: It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium.

options.label: C
options.text: SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Viscoelastic substances, also called ophthalmic visco-surgical devices (OVDs), are used to maintain the anterior chamber shape and volume during cataract surgery, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion. These gel-like materials protect intraocular tissues during surgical procedures and help maintain space in the anterior chamber, making surgical maneuvers safer and easier.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery : This is incorrect. Viscoelastic must be thoroughly removed at the end of surgery as retained viscoelastic can cause post-operative rise in intraocular pressure.
  • • Option A. It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery
  • • Option B. It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium : This is incorrect. Rather than causing damage, viscoelastic substances protect the corneal endothelium from surgical trauma and phacoemulsification energy.
  • • Option B. It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium
  • • Option C. SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics : This is incorrect. These are vitreous substitutes used in vitreoretinal surgery, not viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery.
  • • Option C. SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viscoelastic substances are essential in cataract surgery for maintaining anterior chamber form and protecting intraocular structures, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion, and must be removed at the end of surgery.

questions.text: Posterior interosseous nerve injury causes? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of extension at finger
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Loss of extension at finger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve) supplies all posterior compartment muscles except anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus. Its injury results in finger extension loss while preserving partial wrist extension.

questions.text: Structure which is related deep to marked structure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stem of lateral sulcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pterion is an H-shaped area on the lateral skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid), and it overlies the stem of the lateral sulcus and middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of NCC except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retinal pigment membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neural crest cells give rise to diverse structures including melanocytes, parasympathetic ganglia (including ciliary ganglion), and components of the eye (like ciliary muscles), but the retinal pigment epithelium develops from the optic cup neuroectoderm.

questions.text: NCC derivative for cardiac Structure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Conotruncal Septum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neural crest cells contribute to the development of the conotruncal septum (spiral septum) in the heart, and abnormalities in neural crest cell migration can lead to various congenital heart defects.

questions.text: A patient not able to chew the food and food stuck between cheeks and teeth. Which muscle weakness is associated with this clinical condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Buccinator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The buccinator muscle, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), is essential for keeping food between the teeth during mastication, and its weakness results in food accumulation between cheeks and teeth.

questions.text: Which nerve does the marked structure contain? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the thinnest cranial nerve, emerges from the dorsal midbrain, completely decussates, and supplies only the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: Which nerve is not the content of superior orbital fissure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior orbital fissure transmits cranial nerves III, IV, VI, V1 (including lacrimal, frontal, and nasociliary branches), and associated vessels, while the optic nerve (CN II) passes through the separate optic canal.

questions.text: Identify the type of gland marked in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Holocrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands where the entire cell disintegrates to form the secretion, and they appear as "empty" structures in histological sections because their lipid contents are dissolved during slide preparation.

questions.text: Primary follicles arrest in which phase of prophase 1? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diplotene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary oocytes remain arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis from before birth until puberty, resuming meiosis only when stimulated by hormones during the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: While walking, the suspended leg is supported by which muscle on other side? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gluteus medius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gluteus medius muscle on the stance leg stabilizes the pelvis during walking, preventing the pelvis from dropping on the suspended leg side (Trendelenburg sign when dysfunctional).

questions.text: Epiblast first migration lead to formation of? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoderm

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An elderly man presents with persistent bad breath and a history of dysphagia lasting 7 months. Barium swallow is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zenker’s Diverticulum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Zenker’s diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum occurring at Killian’s dehiscence, a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles. It presents with dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation of undigested food, and chronic symptoms. A barium swallow study confirms the diagnosis by revealing a posterior outpouching in the pharyngoesophageal region.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Esophageal Neoplasia: Typically presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and sometimes hematemesis.
  • • Option A. Esophageal Neoplasia:
  • • Option B. Achalasia: Characterized by dysphagia to both solids and liquids, with a ‘bird-beak’ appearance on barium swallow.
  • • Option B. Achalasia:
  • • Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Causes intermittent chest pain and dysphagia with a ‘corkscrew’ appearance on imaging.
  • • Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal pouch presenting with dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. Diagnosis is confirmed with a barium swallow study.

  • ➤ Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap(AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss. If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed. First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part. If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

questions.text: Which of the following has the worst prognosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Complete B/L RLN palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complete bilateral RLN palsy has the worst prognosis due to both vocal cords being fixed in paramedian position, causing severe airway compromise requiring emergency intervention.
  • ➤ Bilateral RLN palsy:
  • ➤ Both VCs come to lie in the paramedian position. Because all intrinsic muscles are paralyzed on both sides except cricothyroids as they are supplied by SLN. But their action is adduction and tension. Hence, they try to pull the vocal cords medially causing airway obstruction (This is called as Wagner and Grossman theory). Patient presents with a stridor in a life-threatening condition. Emergency tracheostomy is required to restore the airway. 6 months later, if normalisation of VC does not occur, surgical management done which include Lateralisation thyroplasty (Isshiki type II). Cordectomy (by CO2 laser). Posterior transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) Laryngeal reinnervation procedures like nerve muscle implant.
  • ➤ Both VCs come to lie in the paramedian position.
  • ➤ Because all intrinsic muscles are paralyzed on both sides except cricothyroids as they are supplied by SLN.

  • ➤ Hence, they try to pull the vocal cords medially causing airway obstruction (This is called as Wagner and Grossman theory).

questions.text: Which of the following is the first investigation in newborn for audiological assessment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OAE is the first-line screening test for newborn hearing assessment due to its simplicity, speed, and non-invasive nature.
  • ➤ Newborn screening of hearing:
  • ➤ Newborn screening of hearing:
  • ➤ Here we test otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA). Outer hair cells in cochlea emit these very low intensity sounds (OAE) & they can be collected by a microphone kept in EAC. Normal OAE means cochlear hair cells are functioning normally and cochlea is normally functioning. BERA tests the integrity of auditory nerve (auditory pathway from cochlea to brain). It is an objective test. Here we give a sound stimulus and check the electrical potentials that arise along the auditory pathway from cochlear nerve to brain. Wave V is most prominent in BERA that corresponds to lateral lemniscus. It is a non-invasive procedure. It is also an objective test (whereas PTA is a subjective test = result depends on the responses given by patient/subject). Normal BERA means the cochlear nerve is intact and conducting sound impulses from cochlea to brain. So, normal OAE and BERA will indicate an almost normal hearing pathway, hence used in newborn screening. BERA is also used to check malingerers (people those who pretend deaf).

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.
  • • Entry Inhibitors
  • • Entry Inhibitors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Maraviroc : This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.
  • • Option A. Maraviroc
  • • Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.
  • • Option C. Fostemsavir:
  • • Option D. Tenofovir : This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.
  • • Option D. Tenofovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

questions.text: Match the correct antidote with the given drug toxicity: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Benzodiazepine: Flumazenil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Mechanism - it acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. By competitively blocking these receptors, it can rapidly reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and respiratory depression.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Atropine: L-carnitine : Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for atropine poisoning as it can reverse both peripheral and central anticholinergic effects. L-carnitine is used specifically for valproate-induced hepatotoxicity.
  • • Option A. Atropine:
  • • L-carnitine
  • • Option B. Barbiturate: Fomepizole : Incorrect. Barbiturates do not have a specific antidote - management involves alkalinization of urine to enhance excretion. Fomepizole is the antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.
  • • Option B. Barbiturate:
  • • Fomepizole
  • • Option C. Arsenic: Desferrioxamine : Incorrect. British Anti-Lewisite (BAL/Dimercaprol) is the antidote for arsenic poisoning. Desferrioxamine is specifically used for iron poisoning (both acute poisoning and chronic overload).
  • • Option C. Arsenic:
  • • Desferrioxamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antidotes
  • ➤ Antidotes

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs act at the site marked by the arrow? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tiagabine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tiagabine acts by inhibiting GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), which is responsible for the reuptake of GABA from the synapse. By blocking this transporter, Tiagabine increases the synaptic concentration of GABA, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and providing antiepileptic effects. The name "Tiagabine" itself suggests its mechanism - Transport Inhibitor of GABA or GAT-1 inhibitor.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vigabatrin : Incorrect. It inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, not the GABA transporter. This increases GABA levels through a different mechanism.
  • • Option A. Vigabatrin
  • • Option B. Valproate : Incorrect. It has multiple mechanisms of action, primarily involving sodium channel blockade and enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition, but does not specifically target GAT-1.
  • • Option B. Valproate
  • • Option C. Felbamate : Incorrect. It acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist and enhances GABA-mediated inhibition through different mechanisms, not through GAT-1 inhibition.
  • • Option C. Felbamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake by blocking the GABA transporter (GAT-1), leading to increased extracellular GABA and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, making it an effective treatment for epilepsy.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phenytoin : Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.
  • • Option A. Phenytoin
  • • Option B. Lamotrigine : Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.
  • • Option B. Lamotrigine
  • • Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.
  • • Option C. Felbamate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thiopentone except: (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the phenomenon of redistribution

options.label: D
options.text: It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

questions.correct_answer: D. It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution, not rapid renal excretion. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters the brain, causing quick onset of anesthesia. However, it then redistributes to other tissues (muscle and fat), leading to a rapid decrease in brain concentration and therefore a short duration of action. The drug remains in the body but is no longer in sufficient concentration in the brain to maintain anesthetic effects.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug : Correct. Thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, which enables it to rapidly cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • • Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug
  • • Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration : Correct. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly enters the brain within seconds of IV administration.
  • • Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration :
  • • Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution : Correct. After initial brain concentration, thiopentone redistributes to other tissues, particularly muscle and fat.
  • • Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution to other tissues, not rapid renal excretion.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with metastatic breast cancer. She has previously undergone treatment with surgery, radiation, and multiple lines of chemotherapy, but her disease has progressed. Genetic testing reveals a BRCA1 mutation, indicating an impaired DNA repair mechanism. Her cancer is classified as HER2-negative and hormone receptor-positive. Given the genetic findings, her oncologist considers using a therapy that targets the PARP enzyme to exploit the DNA repair vulnerability of her cancer cells. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to prescribe as a PARP inhibitor in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rucaparib

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor. PARP inhibitors work by blocking DNA repair mechanisms in cancer cells. In patients with BRCA mutations (who already have impaired DNA repair), PARP inhibition leads to synthetic lethality and cell death. The name helps identify PARP inhibitors as they end in "parib" (from Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase inhibitor).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Palbociclib: Incorrect. This is a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) 4/6 inhibitor used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While it might be useful in this patient's case, it is not a PARP inhibitor.
  • • Option A. Palbociclib:
  • • Option C. Vorinostat : Incorrect. This is a histone deacetylase inhibitor used in certain hematologic malignancies, not a PARP inhibitor.
  • • Option C. Vorinostat
  • • Option D. Ustekinumab : Incorrect. This is a monoclonal antibody against interleukins used in psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions, not a PARP inhibitor.
  • • Option D. Ustekinumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PARP inhibitors (drugs ending in "parib") are particularly effective in cancers with BRCA mutations due to their mechanism of synthetic lethality in cells with impaired DNA repair.
  • ➤ Breast Cancer
  • ➤ Breast Cancer

questions.text: A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024) Bemepedoic acid Ezetimibe Gemfibrozil Evolocumab
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:
  • • 1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis
  • • Bempedoic
  • • 2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption
  • • Ezetimibe
  • • 4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.
  • • Evolocumab
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • 3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).
  • • 3. Gemfibrozil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding fosphenytoin? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: At high doses in elderly patients, it causes cardiotoxicity and in younger patients nephrotoxicity

options.label: B
options.text: Adverse effects can be avoided if the dose is kept less than 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents

options.label: C
options.text: It is given to all seizure patients in emergency irrespective of CNS adverse effects and hypotension

options.label: D
options.text: High oral dose can result in cerebellar degeneration

questions.correct_answer: B. Adverse effects can be avoided if the dose is kept less than 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adverse effects can be avoided if the dose is kept less than 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin used for IV administration. When the dose is kept below 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents, adverse effects can be minimized. This dosing guideline helps prevent complications while maintaining therapeutic efficacy. After administration, fosphenytoin is converted to phenytoin by phosphatases in blood and liver.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. At high doses in elderly patients, it causes cardiotoxicity and in younger patients nephrotoxicity - Incorrect. Cardiotoxicity can occur at high doses in all age groups, not just elderly. There is no specific age-related difference in nephrotoxicity.
  • • Option A. At high doses in elderly patients, it causes cardiotoxicity and in younger patients nephrotoxicity
  • • Option C. It is given to all seizure patients in emergency irrespective of CNS adverse effects and hypotension - Incorrect. While it's useful in emergency situations, it's not given indiscriminately. CNS effects and hypotension need to be monitored and managed.
  • • Option C. It is given to all seizure patients in emergency irrespective of CNS adverse effects and hypotension
  • • Option D. High oral dose can result in cerebellar degeneration - Incorrect. Fosphenytoin is given intravenously, not orally. While phenytoin can cause cerebellar degeneration, this statement is incorrect for fosphenytoin's route of administration.
  • • Option D. High oral dose can result in cerebellar degeneration -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fosphenytoin's adverse effects can be minimized by keeping the dose below 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents, and it is specifically designed for IV administration.

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The half-life can be calculated using the formula:
  • • t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pretomanid? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used for resistant malaria

options.label: C
options.text: It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

options.label: D
options.text: It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

questions.correct_answer: C. It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pretomanid is approved as part of the BPaL (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) regime for treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) and pre-XDR TB in India. This combination therapy represents a significant advancement in treating highly resistant forms of tuberculosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers : Incorrect. Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, not CYP2C9, and is contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors.
  • • Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers
  • • Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria : Incorrect. Pretomanid is specifically approved for tuberculosis treatment, not malaria.
  • • Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria
  • • Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species : Incorrect. Pretomanid acts by releasing reactive nitrogen species (not oxygen), which inhibit mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.
  • • Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pretomanid is part of the BPaL regimen (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) approved for treating XDR-TB and pre-XDR TB, and works through the release of reactive nitrogen species to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.
  • ➤ New Drugs:
  • ➤ New Drugs:
  • ➤ Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria
  • ➤ Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation
  • ➤ Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation
  • ➤ Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the causes of fall in diastolic blood pressure is correct? (INICET NOV 2024) Loss of sympathetic outflow in the lumbar region Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A fall in diastolic blood pressure primarily occurs due to vasodilation. Two mechanisms listed that cause vasodilation are:
  • • 1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region : Sympathetic system causes vasoconstriction, so its loss leads to vasodilation
  • • 1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region
  • • 3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors : Alpha-1 receptors mediate vasoconstriction, so their blockade causes vasodilation
  • • 3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors : Incorrect. Beta-1 blockade primarily affects heart rate and contractility, leading to decreased systolic blood pressure, not diastolic pressure.
  • • 2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors
  • • 4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors : Incorrect. Beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, so their blockade would cause vasoconstriction and potentially increase diastolic pressure.
  • • 4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diastolic blood pressure is primarily affected by vascular tone - vasodilation decreases it (through loss of sympathetic tone or alpha-1 blockade) while vasoconstriction increases it.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding iron isomaltoside? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: A single bolus dose is enough for treatment of iron deficiency anemia

questions.correct_answer: B. It is given by intravenous route
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is given by intravenous route

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron preparation that can be given via IV route over approximately 30 minutes. It is characterized by having a very low risk of allergic reactions compared to other IV iron preparations. The drug can be administered in high doses, typically requiring 2-3 doses for complete treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside can be safely given with erythropoietin. It's iron ferromoxitol that should be avoided with erythropoietin.
  • • Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin:
  • • Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has very low immunogenicity and is less immunogenic than iron dextran.
  • • Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran:
  • • Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment: Incorrect. Usually 2-3 doses are required for complete treatment, though occasionally one dose might be sufficient.
  • • Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ When standing on one leg, the gluteus medius on the supporting side works hard to prevent your pelvis from dropping towards the non-supporting side.
  • ➤ Weakness in this muscle can lead to a Trendelenburg gait, where the pelvis dips excessively on the unsupported side.

questions.text: Which action will be impacted in PIN Palsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extension of fingers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PIN palsy is a neuropathic compression of the posterior interosseous nerve where it passes through the radial tunnel. This may result in paresis or paralysis of the digital and thumb extensor muscles, resulting in an inability to extend the thumb and fingers at their MCP joints. Wrist extension is preserved due to the action of the extensor carpi radialis longus innervated by the radial nerve.
